A few words will be sufficient to explain the principle on which I have simplified Oaesar's text, the amount of excision, and the degree of change. It would have been a compara tively easy task to simplify the text by the mere process of omission, never deviating from the ipsissimo cerba of the author by so much as the change ol a mode or tense. One could do this and still string together the disjecto membro oi the text into something like a connected narrative. But . that would be to preserve the integrity ol the words attho expense of everything else, - inner relation, structure, style, spirit. Or the simplification might be effected by a virtual rewriting oi the text, by amplification rather than suppresa sion, coupled with changes in the collocatiou ‚of words, where the arrangement seemed to obscure the meaning and perplex the learner.

My purpose and plan differed essentially from both these methods. My aim has been, first, to keep the narrative in- tact; second, to retain as much of the text as was consistent with the effert to disburden it oi its greater difficulties3 third, to make the fewest practicable changes in what was retained, save the modification oi some verb forms, and the occasional rendering of indireot into direct discourse; fourth, very rarely to change the position of a word; finally, never to insert a word, except now and then
